findings.whyItMatters: MFA reduces account takeover risk by requiring additional authentication factors.
findings.remediation: Enable MFA for all user accounts in Azure AD.
findings.title: MFA enabled for user

findings.whyItMatters: Phishing-resistant methods prevent SMS-based attacks and provide stronger security.
findings.remediation: Configure Authenticator app, FIDO2, or Windows Hello for Business as MFA methods.
findings.title: Phishing-resistant MFA methods configured

findings.whyItMatters: MFA must be both enabled and have multiple authentication methods configured for proper security.
findings.remediation: Enable MFA and configure at least one authentication method.
findings.title: MFA properly configured with multiple methods

findings.whyItMatters: Authenticator apps provide better security than SMS-based MFA.
findings.evaluationResult: Rule skipped due to failed dependencies
findings.remediation: Enable Microsoft Authenticator app as an MFA method for users.
findings.title: MFA methods are phishing-resistant

findings.whyItMatters: Valid UPN format ensures proper user identification and authentication.
findings.evaluationResult: Custom evaluator error: Cannot overwrite variable ExecutionContext because it is read-only or constant.
findings.remediation: Ensure all users have valid email-format User Principal Names.
findings.title: User Principal Name follows corporate pattern

findings.whyItMatters: Role assignments should be properly configured and visible.
findings.remediation: Review and properly assign roles to users.
findings.title: User has specific role assignment

findings.whyItMatters: All critical account settings must be properly configured for security compliance.
findings.evaluationResult: Composite AND evaluation: $.AccountEnabled: True $.UserPrincipalName: True $.StrongAuthenticationRequirements[0].State: False -join ', '
findings.remediation: Ensure account is enabled, has valid UPN, and MFA is enforced.
findings.title: User account is fully compliant
